column3: Cognitive-based rules as a means to select suitable groupware tools
column4: Proceedings of the 5th IEEE International Conference on Cognitive Informatics, ICCI 2006
column23:
Learning style models (LSM)
LSM based on Felder-Silverman model
column24:
Learning style
Preferences regarding groupware tools
column26: Used to inform the creation of a method
column34: A method to select a suitable groupware tool that fits the learning styles of members in a given group. The method consists of using a fuzzy set -based machine learning algorithm that learns preference rules from data about people's learning styles and their groupware preferences. The authors position the contribution as being useful in global software engineering because better chosen tools could help with coordination.

column3: Technology selection to improve global collaboration
column4: Proceedings - 2006 IEEE International Conference on Global Software Engineering, ICGSE 2006
column23:
Learning style models (LSM)
LSM based on Felder-Sivlerman model
column24:
Learning style
Preferences regarding groupware tools and requirement elicitation techniques
column25: Questionnaire (learning style + groupware tool and requirement elicitation technique preferences)
column26: Used to inform the creation of a method
column34: A method to select a suitable groupware tool and requirements elicitation technique that fits the learning styles of members in a given group. The method consists of using a fuzzy set -based machine learning algorithm that learns preference rules from data about people's learning styles and their groupware and elicitation technique preferences. The authors position the contribution as being useful in global software engineering because better chosen tools and techniques could help with coordination.

column3: Applying strategies to recommend groupware tools according to cognitive characteristics of a team
column4: Studies in Computational Intelligence
column22: Learning Style Models (LMS) classify people according to a set of behavioral characteristics. Model used in this paper is the Felder-Silverman (FS) model.
column23: Cognitive style (defined by the FS-LMS dimensions)
column24: Satisfaction of communication and produced SRS.
column34: This paper is right on the border of relevance for this review. What is studied is the influence of communication tools on the performance in a SE task (requirements elicitation and specification). While the cognitive profiles of individuals are used, the task is clearly not confined to the individual but a group matter. I would tend to be inclusive on this one and similar papers.

column3: Modeling users on the World Wide Web based on cognitive factors, navigation behavior and clustering techniques
column4: Journal of Systems and Software
column26: Cognitive style is hypothesised to be related to user interface navigation behaviour.
column34: The paper investigates whether cognitive style is related to user interface navigation behaviour. If so, user interface navigation behaviour could be used to infer cognitive style, allowing automatic creation of user profiles/models which could be used as input for development. However, the paper found no reliable relationship. Distinct clusters of navigation behaviour were found, but these did not correspond to cognitive style in terms of the selected theory.

column3: Influence of Confirmation Biases of Developers on Software Quality: An Empirical Study
column4: Software Quality Journal
column23: Cognitive biases, in particular confirmation bias
column25: Wason's rule discorvery task and selection task (answered in a questionnaire)
column34: This seems to be the most comprehensive paper in the series by Calikli on confirmation bias in testing. The metrics (25) to quantify confirmation bias, based on the tasks, are described here in detail. Use this paper to get details. The goal of the paper is to correlate cognitive bias metrics with defect rate metrics. They compared cognitive bias and static code quality measures as predictors for defects. There was no signitificant difference in prediction performance.

column3: Towards a metric suite proposal to quantify confirmation biases of developers

column34: Important work. Confirmation bias connected to defects and performance of groups.

column3: A Conceptual Model of Cognitive Complexity of Elements of the Programming Process
column4: Information and Software Technology
column23: Cognitive complexity and cognitive processes involved in reading and searching code (chunking and tracing) for program comprehension. Chunking is essentially enabled by memory and tracing is a function of knowledge.
column34: Cognitive Complexity Model for program comprehension based on chunking and tracing code. The paper suggests measures that ought to capture complexity of code, on the basis of cognitive processes.
